required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effectiveness of Epidermal Growth Factor-containing Ointment on the Solar Lentigines
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized Controlled Trial on the Effectiveness of Epidermal Growth Factor-containing Ointment on the Treatment of Solar Lentigines as Adjuvant Therapy

lead_sponsor.agency: Hallym University Kangnam Sacred Heart Hospital

clinical_study.source: Hallym University Kangnam Sacred Heart Hospital

brief_summary.textblock:
Subjects were randomly assigned to groups for treatment with either an EGF-containing ointment (the study group) or the vehicle alone (petrolatum; the control group). The EGF ointment included recombinant human EGF (1 μg/g). Random numbers used for assignment to groups were provided by the randomization function of SAS.
The subjects received one session of laser treatment with a Q-switched (QS) 532-nm Nd:yttrium aluminum garnet (YAG) laser of their solar lentigines after enrollment. . The end point of laser treatment for lentigines was immediate whitening. The subjects then applied the EGF ointment or vehicle twice daily (morning and evening) to the lesion for 4 weeks after laser treatment.

primary_outcome.measure: Change of pigmentation by physician's assessment
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline pigmentation at 4 weeks
primary_outcome.description: The pigment clearance was assessed using a 5-grade percentage improvement scale grade 1, <0% [worse]; grade 2, 0%-25% improvement; grade 3, 26%-50% improvement; grade 4, 51%-75% improvement; grade 5, 76%-100% improvement -> higher score means better outcomes

primary_outcome.measure: Change of pigmentation by physician's assessment
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline pigmentation at 8 weeks
primary_outcome.description: The pigment clearance was assessed using a 5-grade percentage improvement scale grade 1, <0% [worse]; grade 2, 0%-25% improvement; grade 3, 26%-50% improvement; grade 4, 51%-75% improvement; grade 5, 76%-100% improvement -> higher score means better outcomes

secondary_outcome.description: A spectrophotometer was used to assess the lesion in a room at constant temperature (20-24 °C) and humidity (28%-38%). Skin measurements were performed to determine erythema.

A VapoMeter®(Delfin Technologies Ltd., Kuopio, Finland) was used to assess the lesion in a room at constant temperature (20-24 °C) and humidity (28%-38%). Skin measurements were performed to determine transepidermal water loss

A VapoMeter®(Delfin Technologies Ltd., Kuopio, Finland) was used to assess the lesion in a room at constant temperature (20-24 °C) and humidity (28%-38%). Skin measurements were performed to determine transepidermal water loss

The patient's subjective satisfaction was assessed by questionnaire according to the following: 1, worse; 2, no change; 3, mild improvement; 4, moderate improvement; or 5, significant improvement. higher score means better outcome

The patient's subjective satisfaction was assessed by questionnaire according to the following: 1, worse; 2, no change; 3, mild improvement; 4, moderate improvement; or 5, significant improvement. higher score means better outcome

arm_group.arm_group_label: epidermal growth factor (EGF) containing ointment group
arm_group.description: The subjects received one session of laser treatment with a Q-swithced (QS) 532-nm Nd:yttrium aluminum garnet (YAG) laser after enrollment. The procedure parameters were as follows: 5-10-ns pulse duration, 3.5-mm spot size, 0.9-1.1-J/cm2 fluence, and 2-Hz frequency. The end point of laser treatment for lentigines was immediate whitening. The subjects then applied the epidermal growth factor (EGF) ointment twice daily (morning and evening) to the lesion for 4 weeks after laser treatment.

The subjects received one session of laser treatment with a Q-swithced (QS) 532-nm Nd:yttrium aluminum garnet (YAG) laser of their solar lentigines after enrollment. The procedure parameters were as follows: 5-10-ns pulse duration, 3.5-mm spot size, 0.9-1.1-J/cm2 fluence, and 2-Hz frequency. The end point of laser treatment for lentigines was immediate whitening. The subjects then applied the vehicle ointment twice daily (morning and evening) to the lesion for 4 weeks after laser treatment.

intervention.description: The subjects applied the epidermal growth factor (EGF) ointment twice daily (morning and evening) to the lesion for 4 weeks after laser treatment.
intervention.arm_group_label: epidermal growth factor (EGF) containing ointment group
intervention.other_name: Easyef Saesal ointment, Daewoong Pharmaceutical Co., Ltd., Seoul, Korea

intervention.description: To compare the effect of epidermal growth factor (EGF) ointment, the control subjects applied the vehicle ointment twice daily (morning and evening) to the lesion for 4 weeks after laser treatment.

The subjects received one session of laser treatment with a Q-swithced (QS) 532-nm Nd:yttrium aluminum garnet (YAG) laser of their solar lentigines after enrollment. The procedure parameters were as follows: 5-10-ns pulse duration, 3.5-mm spot size, 0.9-1.1-J/cm2 fluence, and 2-Hz frequency. The end point of laser treatment for lentigines was immediate whitening.
intervention.arm_group_label: epidermal growth factor (EGF) containing ointment group
intervention.other_name: Nd:yttrium aluminum garnet laser (Iris, Bluecore Company Co., Ltd., Busan, Korea)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Clinical diagnosis of solar lentigines that occurred after adulthood
- age of 20 years or older.
Exclusion Criteria:
- uncontrolled systemic or chronic disease
- hypersensitivity to the ingredients of the ointment
- current use of skin whitening agents
- a history of other laser treatments within the past 6 months
- pregnancy
- lactation.

overall_official.affiliation: Department of Dermatology, Kangnam Sacred Heart Hospital
